quiz.title: Physics Grade 11: Thermodynamics
quiz.subtitle: Unit 7, Quiz 8: The First Law & Work
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: The First Law of Thermodynamics is essentially a statement of which universal principle?
questions.explanation: The First Law ($ \Delta U = Q - W $) states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred as heat or transformed into work.

questions.question: If 500 J of heat is added to a gas and the gas does 200 J of work on its surroundings, what is the change in internal energy (ΔU)?
questions.explanation: Using $ \Delta U = Q - W $: $ \Delta U = 500	ext{ J} - 200	ext{ J} = 300	ext{ J} $.

questions.question: A gas is compressed by an external force, doing 150 J of work ON the gas. At the same time, 100 J of heat is released by the gas. What is ΔU?
questions.explanation: Heat released means $ Q = -100 $. Work done *on* the gas means $ W = -150 $. $ \Delta U = (-100) - (-150) = 50	ext{ J} $.

questions.question: A gas expands from a volume of 0.02 m³ to 0.05 m³ at a constant pressure of 100,000 Pa. How much work is done by the gas?
In an 'Isochoric' process, the volume of the gas remains constant. How much work is done by the gas in this process?
questions.explanation: Since $ \Delta V = 0 $, the formula $ W = P\Delta V $ results in zero work. All heat added goes directly into changing internal energy.

questions.question: A system undergoes a process where the internal energy decreases by 400 J while 200 J of work is done ON the system. How much heat was exchanged?
What does a negative value for Work (W) signify in the standard First Law equation (ΔU = Q - W)?
options: Work is being done ON the system by the surroundings.
Work is being done BY the system on the surroundings.
questions.explanation: By convention, $ W $ is positive when the system does work (expansion) and negative when work is done on the system (compression).

questions.question: During an 'Adiabatic' process, no heat is exchanged with the surroundings (Q = 0). If a gas does work during an adiabatic expansion, what happens to its temperature?
questions.explanation: Since $ \Delta U = -W $, if the gas does work ($ W $ is positive), $ \Delta U $ must be negative. Since internal energy is proportional to temperature, the temperature drops.

questions.question: A piston compresses a gas with a constant pressure of 200 kPa, reducing the volume by 0.004 m³. Calculate the work W.
If a system is perfectly insulated and work is done ON the system, what is the change in internal energy?
questions.explanation: In an insulated system, $ Q = 0 $. Therefore, $ \Delta U = 0 - W $, or $ \Delta U = -W $. If $ W $ is negative (work on system), $ \Delta U $ is positive.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a strong grasp of thermodynamic work and energy balance.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. Review the sign conventions for work done on vs. by a system.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on the First Law equation: ΔU = Q - W.
